thread.title: Chinese property investors from Sydney buy up Melbourne houses
thread.title_full: Chinese property investors from Sydney buy up Melbourne houses

author: Christine de Silva
title: Chinese property investors from Sydney buy up Melbourne houses
text:
A SYDNEY investor beat off stiff competition from local buyers to secure a large home in Melbourne’s outer northeast suburbs.
Although he had only seen the property on FaceTime, the buyer — a man of Chinese descent — was determined, knocking out local bidders to secure the house which appealed for reasons including its positive Feng Shui.
“We had a massive amount of interest in the property that sold within three weeks of hitting the market,” Barry Plant Mill Park/South Morang agent Vivienne Chen said.
The five-bedroom house with three bathrooms at 1 Alexis Close, South Morang, 40km from the CBD, sold for $722,000.
FACETIME VIEWING
THE buyer of Chinese descent made an irresistible offer the vendor couldn’t refuse, according to Ms Chen.
“He did not personally inspect the property but viewed it on FaceTime (video phone call),” she said.
“He plans to lease the home.”
Drawn by the affordability factor and good infrastructure, buyers from Sydney are showing strong interest in this area, Ms Chen said.
The ancient oriental belief in the Feng Shui principles of placement and positive energy heavily influences buyers of Chinese heritage, she said.
“This home’s design and location at the highest point of the street overlooking lakes and mountains met Feng Shui criteria,” she said.
“This house had a bedroom next to a bathroom at ground level, ideal for elderly parents or independent children,” she said.
Big houses on large blocks with five bedrooms or more are sought-after by multi-generational families, according to Ms Chen.
The number of five-bedroom houses sold across Melbourne in the year to June 30 increased by 25 per cent, according to the Real Estate Institute of Victoria.
A total of 963 five-bedroom homes were sold compared to just 768 in 2013-2014.
SIX BIDDERS
ONE of the top sales for the week was a four-bedroom house at 25 The Lakes Blvd, South Morang.
A luxury house at 25 The Lakes Blvd, South Morang, was snapped up by a young family from Mill Park. Source: Supplied
The luxury home on a 603sq m block sold under the hammer for $681,000 on August 22.
A crowd of about 70 people turned up on the sunny winter’s day to watch six bidders compete for the home, said Harcourts Epping agent Justin Sciola.
“A young family from Mill Park snapped up the home at a price that was pretty much on the vendor’s money,” Mr Sciola said.
christine.desilva@news.com.au
Originally published as Facetime buyer swoops
